13.text:
Join me as the history of these hills comes
to life next on Missouri Outdoors.

39.text:
Hi and welcome to Missouri Outdoors, I’m

Today we’re in the Ozarks of southern Missouri
one of the most scenic regions of the state.

74.text:

87.text:
During the past century, Missouri’s forests
have changed dramatically.

92.text:
The early decades of the 1900s saw many of
these hills stripped of their timber.

98.text:
The lumber was used for a growing country
but there was little regard for the natural

105.text:
Trees not cut were many times burned part
of a local tradition thought to promote the

110.text: growth of grasses and destroy ticks and snakes.

113.text:
The land was also choked by livestock grazing,
drought and erosion.

119.text: And as the forests dwindled, so did the wildlife.

122.text:
It would take a lot of education, fire suppression,
replanting of trees and proper management

129.text: to bring the forests and the resources back.

133.text:
Efforts by the Missouri Department of Conservation
would lead the way.

138.text: Help would also come from private individuals.

141.text:
One in particular has spent more than 50 years
building the foundation for strong and healthy

146.text:
forests not only during his lifetime, but
for future generations as well.

148.text:
It’s a pioneering practice started by one
that today benefits all.

156.text:
Narrator: In this small office in downtown

171.text: Slowly, quietly, patiently, the forest grew.

193.text: And this was not a small dream.

216.text:
150,000 acres, stretching across five counties

226.text:
Preserving and protecting the environment
through a vast section of Missouri’s Ozarks.

237.text: That dreamers name is Leo Drey.

Narrator: Drey’s contributions to Missouri’s

And many other significant natural areas were

When the spectacular Greer Spring was threatened

development he immediately took action to

At some point during the discussions, Leo

594.text:
And the natural beauty of that will be preserved

Narrator: Leo Drey also started the Open Space

608.text:
He provided leadership and support for environmental

613.text:
In 2003 Leo and his wife Kay completed their
greatest achievement; the donation of the

624.text:
entire 154,000 acre Pioneer Forest, to a private
charitable foundation.

629.text:
The purpose was to insure that vast tract
of Ozark land, critically important to the

638.text:
watersheds of the Current and Jack’s Fork
River systems would be managed sustainably,

644.text: and be open to the public forever.

648.text:
It was a staggering achievement; the largest

ten philanthropic gifts of for the previous
year.

680.text:
The value we calculated of the donation of

685.text:
dollars, so a huge gift, and a wonderful gift
for Missouri.

Narrator: Many of Leo Drey’s battles are

Over ninety years old, Leo and his wife Kay

835.text:
Narrator: History remembers great men by the
deeds they’ve accomplished.

841.text: In Leo Drey’s case it’s a staggering legacy.

846.text:
Huge tracts of land preserved, new management
techniques developed, environmental groups

853.text:
created and nurtured, charitable giving on
a monumental scale.

863.text:
His dreams are larger than any of us could
imagine, and he’s had the drive, persistence

871.text: and creativity to make those dreams come true.

875.text:
But there is another more subtle measure of
great men.

879.text:
It can be found in the hearts of the people
around them.

Clint: You know, if I hadn’t taken this

895.text:
But having worked with Leo and knowing the

His values, his long tern vision, his dedication

917.text:
this one of the most enjoyable experiences

Kipp: Although these hills are relatively

Century-old stories about the great logging

944.text:
But for some, reminders of the past are found

952.text:
Narrator: Nestled among the Ozark hills of

961.text:
Today, it’s one of the top destinations
for recreational floaters who use canoes,

967.text:
kayaks and rubber rafts to make their way

971.text:
But years ago, this river and others in the

977.text:
one that traces its roots back to Missouri’s
tall timber.

984.text:
In the late 18 and early 19-hundreds, the
region was the site of great activity.

990.text:
Railroad ties and lumber produced from the
Ozark forests helped develop the nation.

995.text:
Lumber for growing cities and ties for the
railroads stretching across the plains.

1002.text:
It was a time when the Ozark forests meant
jobs; back breaking manual labor for men with

1009.text:
Robert: Between livestock and timber, that’s
about all there was.

1014.text:
Narrator: Trees were cut and many times, railroad
ties were created on-site.

1021.text:
Tie Hackers, as they were called, earned ten
cents for each tie produced.

1025.text: They could hew a tie in about one hour.

1028.text:
But getting the wood to their destination
was no easy chore.

1032.text:
Ray Joe: You have to remember that there were
no roads, other than wagon trails, back then.

1039.text: So the river was the main way for transportation.

1044.text:
Narrator: Many ties and logs were moved by
a river drive to the nearest railroad crossing

1050.text:
Some of the larger river drives contained
more than two hundred and fifty thousand free-floating

1055.text: ties and took months to complete.

1059.text:
Another method was to attach ties together
to form a long raft.

1062.text:
Ray Joe: They free-floated logs and ties both,
but the main thing down here on ties was they

1072.text: would nail them together with lash poles.

1075.text:
That’s saplings about three or four inches
through, twenty feet long.

1081.text:
And raft as many as 12-hundred ties down the
river.

1085.text:
Narrator: The men working these drives were
called ‘river hogs’.

1089.text:
They were wet for weeks on end for a dollar
seventy five a day.

1093.text: It was not a job to be envied.

1097.text:
When the drive reached the railroad crossing,
men, teams of horses and mules, and wagons

1103.text:
would be standing by to pull the ties from
the river and carry them to waiting railroad

While the Current River is no longer an avenue

1419.text:
Martha Daniels: If you’re looking for a
sweet and nutty dessert or just a special

1446.text: snack treat, we’ve got the recipe for you.

1450.text:
Our blackberry-pecan squares have a buttery
toffee flavor, enhanced by toasted pecans.

1455.text:
And it’s all complimented by the wonderful
taste of blackberries.

1460.text:
First, grease an 8 inch square baking pan
with butter and set aside.

1464.text: Stir together flour, soda and salt.

1467.text:
Cream butter and sugar with a mixer about
3 minutes until fluffy.

1475.text: Add eggs and vanilla and beat.

1478.text:
Continue to beat slowly, adding in the flour
mixture until combined.

1485.text: Gradually add 3/4 cup toasted pecans and mix.

1490.text: Then spread the batter in a pan.

1493.text:
Sprinkle berries on top, and scatter on remaining
nuts.

1498.text: Bake at 325 degrees for 50 to 55 minutes.

1506.text:
Let it cool for 30 minutes and sprinkle with
powdered sugar.

1513.text:
Getting out on a summer morning to pick blackberries
is a refreshing experience, especially when

1518.text:
you know everyone will relish the sweet berry
flavors in blackberry pecan squares.

1524.text:

or just write to us.

1527.text:
We’ll have the address for you at the end
of the show.

1541.text:

1544.text: All you have to do is go surfing!

If you love to hike, we’ve got the trail
for you!

1549.text:
You can find a nice hike close to home by
searching trails by county.

1553.text:
Or find a special spot by selecting the class
of trail you prefer, like a primitive or disable-accessible

1561.text:
Or choose the type of trail you want: something
that offers an interpretive hike or one that

1565.text:
allows horses or bicycles, in addition to
hikers.

1569.text:
And you can even access information on the
adopt-a-trail program.

1573.text:
To make surfing Missouri easy, our web site
is designed to work with any web browser.

1577.text:
Use our web address or type “Missouri conservation”
into any search engine.

Thanks for watching, and don't forget, if
